utterances: I think we need to get more, you know, crossover - come over, crossover thing going on.

If you talk about the whole buying black thing, I mean, get some white folks, get some Hispanic folks, and whoever to get on board, which is say, hey, you know, we see a need, help us to meet this need.
I don't like to be exclusive about it in saying that black people support black people.
If there is a need, if there is a problem, there's issue of racism, we're not going to solve it by ourselves as black people.
We need to get everybody to come to the table and participate in this thing.
I want to actually move us on to politics.
There's a couple of big topics - Hillary Clinton, Fred Thompson.
Earl, Senator Hillary Clinton's opponents pulled out their boxing gloves and accused her of playing the gender card.
And so last Friday, Senator Barack Obama said that Clinton was playing the gender card for saying, don't pick on me after being attacked during the presidential debate.

And Clinton said she was being forced, quote, ""to compete in the all-boys club during the election run."" Do you think that that's fair on either side - accusing someone of basically being thin-skinned or accusing the other side of using gender as a weapon?
He was starting in the Peking University for Ph.D. And he has really two good life friends and also classmates.
Well, yes, frankly.
I mean, there are thin-skinned candidates and that's going to be a point that you can bring out, that's going to a point you can play off.
Senator Clinton definitely played the gender card, no doubt about it.
She backed away from it with a quickness, okay, because it was absurd.
She's got to play on the same field as everyone else.
But she did go after that gut reaction from the female, the women - my daughter gets me for saying females instead of women.
She got the gut reaction from the women in the world so like, what?
Those guys are jumping on her.
Now they'll back off and think about it.
They'll make their judgments, but they've still got that initial gut reaction that they're going to factoring into it.
So I think she was successful at it, but she definitely did it.
Do you think that's fair, John?
Do you think it's fair for a female candidate no matter how powerful to say, you know, gender is playing a role in this?
No, it's not fair.
And Obama is absolutely right, that she was playing the gender card.
But let me say this, at the same time, you know, I'm not necessarily loving on Obama right now anyway, because all of them, all they're doing is playing the game.

The thing I don't like about this whole thing is that, yeah, while Obama is right that Hillary pulled out this gender card, let me tell you what, if Hillary Clinton ends up getting the nomination, guess who's going to be right there clamoring for a job, clamoring to be vice president?
Barack Obama.
It's not going to happen.
So if you hate Hillary Clinton now, when the time comes for the nomination, you got to still have that same type of hate, politically speaking.
Farai, let mo go the other way on this.
Okay.
You know, politics is a bottom-line business.
And the reality is you have to do whatever you think you need to do to win.
Now 54 to 58 percent of American voters, depending on the source, are women.
You should be a fool to not try to reach out to women.

And quite frankly, you know, it seems to me that the reason why these candidates are upset about it is because they can't use that to their own benefit, just as other candidates can't use their race as a benefit to the extent that Barack Obama can.
You know, they all sort of, have to, sort of back off of Hillary Clinton when it comes to gender issues.

And - so I'm not terribly a bit ashamed about it, in the long run, it's not going to make much of a difference because the people who are going to make the decision when electing her are going to do so on a range of issues and I think gender is going to find its - going to find itself down the list a bit.
All right, guys, well, just stay with me.
We're going to be back with more of the Bloggers' Roundtable.
Talking to Michael Fauntroy of MichaelFauntroy.com, Earl Dunovant of Prometheus 6, and John McCann of The Book of John.
From the streets of Iraq to a very different kind of war in Haiti.
There you'll find one of the world's largest and deadliest slums, Cite Soleil.
The U.N.
once dubbed that the most dangerous place on Earth.
Gang violence erupted there in 2004 after the government of then President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was overthrown.

Danish filmmaker Asger Leth traveled to the notorious slum right before Aristide's ouster, and his latest film, ""Ghosts of Cite Soleil,"" follows two rival gang leaders, who also happened to be blood brothers.
Asger, welcome to the show.
Thank you very much.
Let's begin with this.
The title of the film is ""Ghosts of Cite Soleil."" Why that?
Why that?
Yeah.
Well, you know, these gangs are called the Shamere(ph).
You know, the gangs were like operating as almost as secret army, which is interesting.
Now, you just talked about Iraq just before.
I mean, the Shameres, it roughly translates as ghosts somehow.
And also while I wrote the title early on, I had a feeling that these guys in the gangs would probably end up dead, and that's actually also what happened.
So in that sense, it's become a double title for me.
I mean now, they are literally are ghosts, these guys, you know?
The gangs have caused massive killings and devastation in the city.
And there's a clip from the film that features a news report about the up-rise of Aristide's gang after he was overthrown.
Here it is.
(Soundbite of film ""Ghosts of Cite Soleil"")

Unidentified Man #1: What started as a gang uprising in the city of Bonaive(ph) has now come under the control of men who used to be officers in Haiti's Army, an army Aristide disbanded in part because of its abysmal human rights record.
The killed more than 5,000 people, now they are back to kill more people.

You know, you had what seemed to be unfettered access to the members of the Shamere gang that you followed, and in one scene in particular, someone, it may have been Billy, I'm not sure, turned the gun directly to the camera, and said, and this is a quote, ""I should take your camera."" Now, it - he didn't look to me like he was kidding, tell me about…
No.
…the personal danger you experienced in making this film.
Well, that guy wasn't kidding.
It wasn't Billy, though, it was just another local guy from the slum.
I mean, that's the - I mean, it's a pretty intense place to be in, you know?
But I shot this film together with the Serbian filmmaker, Milos Loncarevic, and the Danish cinematographer Frederik Jacobi.
And, luckily, Milos spent most of the time inside the slum, and that image in particular, that guy was threatening Milos, you know.
But Milos grew up during the war in Belgrade so he's just kind of used a little bit of everything.

But, I mean, you know, inside the slum, we're all under the protection of the gang somehow because we made a, you know, we asked them if they wanted to tell the story and they wanted to tell the story.
We're out one morning and there it was, all (unintelligible) beautiful was the icicles hanging all over the leaves, every one of them; it's like Lou and I were saying, what are we - what next?
What are we going to do here?
Unlike the big citrus growers, the Pasquales can't afford crop insurance.
We totally feel like we're being overlooked - we're left out.
There's nothing wrong with the, you know, with the big guys, but it's just that we need to be acknowledged also.
And we have not been.
Many of the small farmers who have been hardest hit are Southeast Asians.
Jang Pau Hur(ph) is Hmong refugee from Laos.
He's showing some freeze-burned broccoli and mustard greens to farm advisers who work with the University of California.
They're here to check on Hur's crop.
This one is still good to eat.
(Unintelligible)
Yeah, right in the middle there.
But that's a defect, when it turns black there from the frost.
Like most Southeast Asian farmers, Hur grows winter crop like bok choy, Napa cabbage and lemongrass.
He drives to Santa Barbara twice a week to the farmers market, but he hasn't set up his stall there since December because he's lost 80 percent of his crop.
He holds up a bunch of Bok choy that looks nice and green on the outside, but it's mushy when he cuts it open.
(Soundbite of cutting)
No good vegetables.
I don't take them in the market because they're black and yellow, and when you cook it sour.
After that, you lose customers.
Hur has lost five weeks of income already, and he doesn't expect to have any vegetables to sell for another month.
He's been scraping by using his savings to feed his 10 children and buy fertilizer.
If for one more month, it be my money - my savings will be gone then.
I don't what to do.
This week, the federal government issued a disaster declaration for California counties hit by the freeze.
That makes emergency low interest loans available to growers.
But small immigrant farmers like Hur probably won't apply for them.
Farm adviser Richard Moliner(ph) says many immigrant farmers don't own their land and don't have the assets to qualify for loans.
Others are reluctant to take on debt.
The paper work is beyond most of the capabilities of the Hmong farmers.
Because it's many, many pages long.
It's going to require some kind of credit history or history back five years that - to prove what has been lost.
They're not going to be able to do it in most cases.
Fresno's new Hmong city councilmen is considering one solution, having the city back zero interest loans for small farmers hit by the freeze.
The council will likely vote on that idea next week.
For NPR News, I'm Sasha Khokah in Fresno.
(Soundbite of music)
This is NPR News.
